full_text:
Case 22-1426, Document 101, 03/10/2024, 3614237, Page2 of 2
Catherine O'Hagan Wolfe
March 10, 2023
Page 2 of 2
The same principles apply to the statute of limitations at issue here. (See Gov. Br. 42-49). That statute covers an "offense involving the sexual or physical abuse . . . of a child," 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 (2003), which similarly "suggests factual details surrounding the charged conduct" and lacks language like "has as an element." And it is also part of a statute intended to afford broader protections for minor victims of crimes. See, e.g., Weingarten v. United States, 865 F.3d 48, 54 (2d Cir. 2017).
Respectfully submitted,
DAMIAN WILLIAMS
United States Attorney
By:     /s/
Andrew Rohrbach
Maurene Comey
Lara Pomerantz
Hagan Scotten
Assistant United States Attorneys
Tel: (212) 637-1944
cc: Diana Fabi Samson, Esq. (via CM/ECF)
DOJ-OGR-00021791

Page 2 of 2

The same principles apply to the statute of limitations at issue here. (See Gov. Br. 42-49). That statute covers an "offense involving the sexual or physical abuse . . . of a child," 18 U.S.C. ยง 3283 (2003), which similarly "suggests factual details surrounding the charged conduct" and lacks language like "has as an element." And it is also part of a statute intended to afford broader protections for minor victims of crimes. See, e.g., Weingarten v. United States, 865 F.3d 48, 54 (2d Cir. 2017).
